results.title: Black hawk down
results.creator_credit: Revolution Studios, Columbia Pictures, Jerry Bruckheimer and Ridley Scott
results.brief_description: Based on actual events, Ridley Scott’s “Black Hawk down” chronicles a disastrous and bloody U.S military battle in Mogadishu, Somalia. Set in the later part of 1993, “Black Hawk down” follows a group of US army rangers whose mission is to capture two top lieutenants of Somalian warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid. However, the mission proves fatal when the elite team are dropped down by helicopter into Mogadishu and find themselves at the mercy of Somalian gunmen. Director Ridley Scott and cinematographer Slawomir Idziak have created a vision of war that is pure chaos. Before we even have a chance to learn the names of the unfortunate U.S. soldiers, we are quickly dropped into the middle of battle with them, experiencing their confusion, their terror, as the situation gets wildly out of hand. Ultimately little else is explored in this vision of visceral horror, the Somalians becoming mere specters faintly glimpsed through opaque dust clouds, while the politics of war are left quietly alone. What emerges is the quintessential war film, acts of heroism in the face of adversity and the nobility of male to male comradeship in the line of duty. Cast includes: Josh Hartnett, Ewen McGregor, Tom Sizemore, Eric Bana, William Fichtner, Ewen Bremner, Sam Shepard and Orlando Bloom.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Revolution Studios, Columbia Pictures, Jerry Bruckheimer and Ridley Scott

results.title: Black harvest
results.creator_credit: Arundel Productions, Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson
results.brief_description: Black Harvest is an extremely moving real-life drama of two ambitious men vying for power, of two cultures in conflict as a dream of wealth turns sour. In the highlands of Papua New Guinea, Joe Leahy, a mixed race Highlander and wealthy coffee plantation owner, joins forces with the Ganiga tribe to expand his empire. His greatest ally is the Ganiga tribal leader, Popina Mai, who wants to take his people into the modern world quickly. But on the eve of the coffee harvest, the work ethic and promises of wealth are abandoned as tribal warfare and tragedy erupt. This is the final part of a trilogy on the Ganiga people (“First Contact” and “Joe Leahy’s Neighbours”) made by award- winning filmmakers, Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson.

results.title: Black gold, kindred spirits
results.brief_description: The Wonthaggi State Coal Mine was arguably the most dangerous mine in Australia. Using archival footage and interviews, this film captures the spirit of Wonthaggi, her mateship and her community spirit, as elicited from the men and women who lived through the mine’s strongest days. The mine opened in 1909, and the last whistle rang in 1968, signifying the end to a place of danger and industrial turmoil. It was from this environment of danger that the workplace created a solidarity amongst workers that is both encouraging and astonishing. ‘Black gold, kindred sprit’ is a testament to this community spirit.

results.title: Black Fire (Blackfire)
results.brief_description: Blackfire is one of the first film ever directed by an Aboriginal person. It is a collection of connected ideas and a take on both the state of Anthropology and Aboriginal Affairs in 1972.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.description:
Blackfire is one of the first film ever directed by an Aboriginal person. It is a collection of connected ideas and a take on both the state of Anthropology and Aboriginal Affairs in 1972.

results.title: Black eye
results.creator_credit: Pat Rooney Production, Pat Rooney and Jack Arnold
results.brief_description: Since being forced to give up his police badge following a suspension from duties, Shep Stone (Fred Williamson) has tried his hand at P.I work. Arriving home to his apartment one evening Stone finds a murder victim, and a killer waiting. Cast includes Fred Williamson, Rosemary Forsyth, Teresa Graves and Floy Dean. Based on the novel “Murder on the wild side” by Jeff Jacks.

results.title: Black dogs
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Luigi Acquisto and Andrew Sully
results.brief_description: A short Melbourne comedy which explores the complications that arise when a gothic punk woman and her racist skinhead boyfriend move next door to a Vietnamese-Australian couple in Melbourne’s western suburbs. Funny and astute, “Black Dogs” pokes gentle fun at some of the eccentricities of youth subcultures without being patronising or offensive. Sharply written and directed, this gem of a movie manages to entertain as it examines some of the tensions of modern “multicultural” Australia. The acting by the young cast is faultless.

results.title: Black cloud over Bali
results.brief_description: In March 1963, Bali’s holy mountain, Gurung Agung, erupted. Over a wide area there was darkness and rain and thousands fled their homes. Molten lava poured down the mountainside killing 1,500 people; 189,000 acres of rice paddy fields were destroyed and a wide area was covered in volcanic ash. Narrated by Denis Mathews.

results.title: Black chicks talking [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: BungaburBungabura Productions, SBS Independent, Bain Stewart and Leah Purcell
results.brief_description: Performer and writer Leah Purcell talks with five very different Indigenous women - Rosanna Angus, Kathryn Hay, Deborah Mailman, Cilla Malone and Tammy Williams - about what it means to be Aboriginal in Australia today. In a series of individual interviews and at one lively dinner party, the women frankly share their life experiences and opinions. Though their backgrounds are extremely diverse, common themes of culture, family, racism and denial run through their stories, as does the ongoing personal and social legacy of past government polices of forced removal. The result is a passionate and challenging exploration of black identity. Teachers notes available through Film Australia at: http://www.filmaust.com.au/programs/default.asp?content=teachers_notes

results.title: Black cat, white cat
results.creator_credit: CiBy 2000, Pandora Films, Komuna, Karl Baumgartner and Emir Kusturica
results.brief_description: Bosnian-born filmmaker, Emir Kusturica, made this farcical comedy set in a Gypsy settlement along the banks of the Danube, where three generations of characters burst forth in manic and frenetic displays of charm, confusion and chaos. The story is built around two old friends and their families who become impossibly entangled in a marriage of inconvenience. With a soundtrack of Gypsy music and songs, the funny film features numerous non-professional in the cast. In Serbo-Croation with English subtitles. Cast includes: Bajram Severdzan, Florijan Ajdini, Salija Ibraimova, Branka Katic and Srdjan Todorovic.
